title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
Welcome to the course!
This course is designed to introduce you to the basics of data analytics, machine learning and Artificial Intelligence (AI). We also introduce some foundational knowledge and skills in the powerful programming language Python. It assumes no prior coding experience. Over the semester we progress through three integrated modules: four weeks focused on essential Python skills, four weeks on core machine learning techniques, and four weeks on large language models (LLMs) and contemporary AI applications. Together, these modules build the technical fluency and conceptual understanding needed to engage confidently with data-driven tools and AI systems in academic, professional, and organizational settings.
Why learn Python? Python remains the dominant language for analytics and AI. It combines simple syntax with a very broad system of libraries for conducting this kind of work. It is used extensively across industries, everything from technology and consulting to retail, finance, and healthcare. It is used by organizations such as Google, Amazon, NASA, Deloitte, and countless startups. Its open-source nature also makes it accessible and cost-effective for individuals and firms alike. Developing proficiency in Python enables you to automate tasks, analyze data rigorously, and implement models that support data-informed decision-making.
Machine learning and AI have become essential tools in modern organizations. Firms generate enormous volumes of data, yet competitive advantage depends on the ability to convert that data into actionable insights. Understanding the principles behind predictive models, classification systems, and LLM-based tools is a baseline expectation for emerging business professionals. Whether your future career is in marketing, finance, operations, consulting, or entrepreneurship, the ability to interpret and evaluate AI systems, and to understand their limitations, will enhance your effectiveness in the workplace.
By the end of the course, you will have both (1) practical skills for working with Python and core machine learning methods, and (2) broad AI literacy that enables you to engage thoughtfully with the evolving landscape of intelligent systems.

title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
COURSE OBJECTIVES

Programming and Computational Skills

Programming: Install and configure Python and the required software environment for running analytical and AI-related scripts.

Programming: Read and interpret basic Python programs, recognizing core data types, control structures, and common programming patterns.

Programming: Write and execute Python scripts to manipulate, clean, and prepare data for analytical tasks.

Programming: Diagnose and resolve coding errors through systematic debugging and structured problem-solving strategies.

Computational Foundations: Develop fluency with essential computational workflows (e.g., navigating files, managing environments, and executing scripts) that support professional analytical practice.



Analytics and Data Interpretation

Analytics: Produce foundational data visualizations using standard Python libraries and interpret the patterns and relationships they reveal.

Analytics: Generate descriptive statistical summaries for continuous and categorical variables to support data-driven reasoning and basic inference.



Artificial Intelligence

AI Literacy: Explain the major categories of AI systems—including machine learning models and large language models—and understand the types of problems they are designed to solve.

AI Literacy: Evaluate the capabilities and limitations of AI tools in business contexts, including issues related to data requirements, interpretability, and responsible use.

Machine Learning: Build and evaluate simple machine-learning models to illustrate core concepts such as classification, prediction, generalization, and model validation.
LLM Foundations: Understand how large language models operate at a conceptual level, including tokens, context windows, and the statistical nature of model predictions.

Prompting Skills: Design, refine, and evaluate prompts to achieve reliable, structured, and domain-appropriate outputs from LLMs.

Critical Use of LLMs: Assess the strengths, limitations, and failure modes of LLMs in analytical and business settings, and apply strategies to mitigate common errors or hallucinations.



Applied Analytics and AI in Business

Applied Skills: Understand how Python, machine learning, and large language models are used across business domains to support decision-making, automation, and analytical problem-solving.

Applied Skills: Interpret the outputs of analytical and AI systems and communicate insights in a clear and professional manner.

title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
AI COURSE CONTENT
Each program at the University of Florida designated as an AI course has Student Learning Outcomes (SLOs) that describe the knowledge, skills, and attitudes that students are expected to acquire throughout the program.
This course fits into the UF AI Category “Build AI”. In this course, students will: Evaluate & Create AI: Higher-order thinking skills (e.g., evaluate, appraise, predict, design) with AI applications. AI course content is over 50 percent.
This course has the following identified Student Learning Outcomes, with the corresponding week they are assessed:

SLO1: Identify, describe, and/or explain the components, requirements, and/or characteristics of AI. (Weeks 1, 5, 8-12)
SLO2: Recognize, identify, describe, define, and/or explain applications of AI in multiple domains. (Weeks 6,8,9,12)
SLO3: Select and/or utilize AI tools and techniques appropriate to a specific context and application. (Weeks 5-9)
SLO5: Assess the context-specific value or quality of AI tools and applications. (Weeks 5-12)

When you see these noted in the syllabus, in the schedule, or written somewhere in the course materials- don’t panic. These designations are for the university, they don’t have any direct impact on your grade. If you have questions, let me know!

QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
LECTURES
You will watch prerecorded course lectures within the course website pages. You will be responsible for all material presented in lectures. Lectures occasionally will be used to clarify and summarize the text, but will also include material not covered in the text. Please note that exam and assignment questions may come from material discussed verbally in the lecture. Additional videos may be posted throughout the course to answer student questions. The content of these will not be on the exams. Optional videos will be clearly labeled in the video title, the announcement, or the discussion post. If it is not labeled optional, questions in the exams may draw from the video. The first 6 weeks of the course cover the basics of using Python for data analysis, and the last 7 weeks cover more advanced topics in analytics and AI. Planned gaps in the schedule are for catching up and holidays/breaks.

title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
QUIZZES, SIMULATIONS AND EXAM DETAIL
NOTE: The number and weight of the assignments may be reduced during the semester at the discretion of the instructor. If a quiz or assignment is removed, the points for that assignment are also removed and are no longer considered when calculating the final grade. The module exams get harder, so the first module exam is by far the easiest. The third is almost all conceptual, and covers very advanced topics. You should plan on spending some time preparing for these.

WEEKLY QUIZ
Most weeks of the course have a quiz. The quiz is open book, open notes, and untimed. Each quiz can be taken twice, and the highest score is retained. The due date for the quizzes (always the same each week) is posted on Canvas. I offer a 2-day automatic “grace” period for every quiz. This is intended to be used for emergencies only. The quiz is due on the due date. Without penalty and without approval, you can turn it in up to 2 days late. Keep in mind, of course, that were something to occur during the grace period, this would not be an adequate reason for an extension. You will need to show that you were not able to complete the quiz on time by the original due date, and that the 2-day grace period was inadequate to recover from that incident or problem and take the quiz. I believe these situations will be extremely rare.
At the end of the course, the 2 quizzes with the lowest grade will be dropped (not counted).
The quizzes in this course are designed to give you feedback on your current level of understanding. Many of the questions on the quiz have additional details and feedback available when the wrong/right answer is chosen. Be sure to read this after you have completed the quiz. This is important even if you scored very well; the additional details will help solidify your understanding of the material.
A word about late or missing quizzes: I understand that sometimes life, minor illness, other classes, and just plain mistakes are made, and a quiz is missed or completed late. I don’t want to be the judge and jury of your misfortune. Sometimes bad things happen. The dropped quizzes and automatic grace period of 2 days per quiz allow you the privacy and flexibility to prioritize without worrying about my judgment or having one mistake result in a major grade impact. This grading does not remove an opportunity to make up a quiz due to an excused absence (see below), but given the generous “drop 2” policy and 2 days grace for grading, I would assume these are rare. The quizzes are open for 7 days; students who anticipate issues with conflicting activities should complete the quizzes earlier in the week. I believe, and hope you agree, this policy is clear, fair, and flexible. I ask in return that if you truly need an exception beyond this built-in flexibility, that you are clear and honest about that need.
Some of the questions for the quizzes are from a question pool. You should not expect second attempts at a quiz to be identical. On a retake, the questions may change. The new questions from the pool may look very similar to the first quiz questions. It is critical if you want to improve your grade that you read and complete each question again carefully, and not just plug in your answers from your first quiz attempt.
Throughout the course, you’ll encounter occasional graded survey-style questions. These questions are worth just a few points, and are graded for completion (completing the survey is full points). They are an easy way to add some cushion to your grade. Their purpose is to give you a chance to reflect on your learning and to help me (your instructor) gauge how the class is progressing. Your responses help identify what concepts are clear, what might need more explanation, and how I can improve the course in real time. Your honest input is greatly appreciated and contributes to making this a more responsive and effective learning experience for everyone.


MODULE EXAMS (3)
The module exams exam will be drawn evenly from all lectures, worksheets, and readings that occurred in that module. They are not deliberatly cumulative. By that I mean they do not try and test materials from earlier modules. Each test is meant to stand on its own. That said, the course material builds on itself, so having a firm grasp on prior material won’t hurt. The exams are proctored using Honorlock. Students are not permitted to use the internet or work with others during the exams. Students can and should have a programming environment open for the Module 1 (week 4) and Module 2 (week 8) test.
Open windows: The module exams are open for 7 days. This includes some days where NEW material is introduced. The new material is limited during these weeks, to allow time to prepare for the exam. Module exams, like quizzes have a 2 day grace period. The lighter material introduction + 2 days grace should be more than sufficient to prepare if you have been keeping up in the class so far.


COLLABORATION
Writing code and performing data analytics is often a collaborative exercise. You are free to discuss on Canvas or elsewhere any materials from the lectures or workbooks. Quizzes, simulations, and exams are individual efforts only. Please do not post answers or solutions from these in the forums or elsewhere online.

Use of Generative AI tools or other AI tools
You are permitted to use generative AI tools (such as ChatGPT, GitHub Copilot, or similar technologies) for most course activities, including the graded quizzes, exercises, and assignments. However, AI tools may not be used during the midterm or final exam, which are intended to assess your individual understanding.

title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
CLASS RECORDING
Students are allowed to record video or audio of class lectures. However, the purposes for which these recordings may be used are strictly controlled. The only allowable purposes are (1) for personal educational use, (2) in connection with a complaint to the university, or (3) as evidence in, or in preparation for, a criminal or civil proceeding. All other purposes are prohibited. Specifically, students may not publish recorded lectures without the written consent of the instructor.
A “class lecture” is an educational presentation intended to inform or teach enrolled students about a particular subject, including any instructor-led discussions that form part of the presentation, and delivered by any instructor hired or appointed by the University, or by a guest instructor, as part of a University of Florida course. A class lecture does not include lab sessions, student presentations, clinical presentations such as patient history, academic exercises involving solely student participation, assessments (quizzes, tests, exams), field trips, private conversations between students in the class or between a student and the faculty or lecturer during a class session.
Publication without permission of the instructor is prohibited. To “publish” means to share, transmit, circulate, distribute, or provide access to a recording, regardless of format or medium, to another person (or persons), including but not limited to another student within the same class section. Additionally, a recording, or transcript of a recording, is considered published if it is posted on or uploaded to, in whole or in part, any media platform, including but not limited to social media, book, magazine, newspaper, leaflet, or third party note/tutoring services. A student who publishes a recording without written consent may be subject to a civil cause of action instituted by a person injured by the publication and/or discipline under UF Regulation 4.040 Student Honor Code and Student Conduct Code.
Should all or part of this class or open study sessions be offered via an online mechanism during this semester, our sessions may be audio visually recorded for students in the class to refer back and for enrolled students who are unable to attend live. Students who participate with their camera engaged or utilize a profile image are agreeing to have their video or image recorded. If you are unwilling to consent to have your profile or video image recorded, be sure to keep your camera off and do not use a profile image. Likewise, students who un-mute during class and participate orally are agreeing to have their voices recorded. If you are not willing to consent to have your voice recorded during these sessions, you will need to keep your mute button activated and communicate exclusively using the ”chat” feature, which allows students to type questions and comments live.

title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
Welcome to the course!
This course is designed to introduce you to the basics of data analytics and machine learning using the powerful programming language Python. No prior programming experience is required. The course is structured into two main sections. Students will first learn the basics of Python and how to write programs in Weeks 1-6. Weeks 6+ progress to using Python to solve real world analytical problems.
Why learn Python? Python is rapidly becoming the language of choice fordata scientists, data analysts, and those working on cutting edge business analytics. It is the tool of choice for this work at companies such as Google,Amazon, Facebook, IBM, NASA, Accenture, and Deloitte. It is also free to use, making it widely available to firms and users around the world. Beyond business analytics, Python is often used as a general programming language to automate tasks.
Why learn machine learning? Businesses today often use data to solve complex problems. A business that ignores the data it generates is at a significant disadvantage. The skills required to analyze and interpret that data are in short supply. A basic understanding of Artificial Intelligence and how it is used in business will be critical for tomorrows business leaders. Regardless of the domain a student decides to work in after graduation, it is likely that AI skills will make them more competitive in the job market.

title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
COURSE OBJECTIVES

Programming: Install Python and Jupyter notebooks
Programming: Read basic Python programs, recognizing the structures and patterns within, and be able to explain how they work
Programming: Write and run Python scripts to manipulate, clean, and prepare data for analysis
Programming: Debug and problem solve coding errors
Analytics: Produce basic visualizations using standard Python libraries
Analytics: Produce basic statistical summaries of continuous and categorical data
Artificial Intelligence: Understand the different AI models and approaches businesses use
Artificial Intelligence: Build a simple machine learning model
Applied Analytics and AI: Understand how Python and other business analytics programs can be used in business applications

Each program at the University of Florida designated as an AI course has Student Learning Outcomes (SLOs) that describe the knowledge, skills, and attitudes that students are expected to acquire throughout the program.
This course fits into the UF AI Category “Build AI”. In this course, students will: Evaluate & Create AI: Higher-order thinking skills (e.g., evaluate, appraise, predict, design) with AI applications. AI course content is over 50 percent.

SLO5: Assess the context-specific value or quality of AI tools and applications. (Weeks 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, simulation 2)

QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
LECTURES
You will watch prerecorded course lectures within the course website pages. You will be responsible for all material presented in lectures. Lectures occasionally will be used to clarify and summarize the text, but will also include material not covered in the text. Please note that exam and assignment questions may come from material discussed verbally in the lecture. Additional videos may be posted throughout the course to answer student questions. The content of these will not be on the exams. Optional videos will be clearly labeled in the video title, the announcement, or the discussion post. If it is not labeled optional, questions in the exams may draw from the video. The first 6 weeks of the course cover the basics of using Python for data analysis, and the last 7 weeks cover more advanced topics in analytics and AI. Planned gaps in the schedule are for catching up and holidays/breaks.

title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
QUIZZES, SIMULATIONS AND EXAM DETAIL
NOTE: The number and weight of the assignments may be reduced during the semester at the discretion of the instructor. If a quiz or assignment is removed, the points for that assignment are also removed and are no longer considered when calculating the final grade. The final exam is harder than the midterm and the quizzes, so it is advisable to go into the final exam with a very good grade.

SIMULATIONS
The simulation exercises test your understanding of the material to that date in the course. The first exercise has more coding, while the second exercise is almost exclusively related to testing your knowledge, understanding, and application of the analytics and AI approaches discussed in the lectures.
Note on Grading the Simulation Assignments: This simulation is intentionally challenging and designed to stretch your thinking. To ensure the grading reflects effort and relative mastery rather than absolute perfection, final scores will be curved based on the top 25% of performers. The average score of that top quartile will be mapped to full credit (40 points), and all other scores will be scaled proportionally. This approach ensures fairness while maintaining high standards. In practical terms this means when receiving your grade for this exercise, you should not panic. Once the exercise is complete, the curve will be calculated. The grades and the mapping used to generate them will be posted.


WEEKLY QUIZ
Most weeks of the course have a quiz. The quiz is open book, open notes, and untimed. Each quiz can be taken twice, and the highest score is retained. The due date for the quizzes (always the same each week) is posted on Canvas. I offer a 2-day automatic “grace” period for every quiz. This is intended to be used for emergencies only. The quiz is due on the due date. Without penalty and without approval, you can turn it in up to 2 days late. Keep in mind, of course, that were something to occur during the grace period, this would not be an adequate reason for an extension. You will need to show that you were not able to complete the quiz on time by the original due date, and that the 2-day grace period was inadequate to recover from that incident or problem and take the quiz. I believe these situations will be extremely rare.
At the end of the course, the 2 quizzes with the lowest grade will be dropped (not counted).
The quizzes in this course are designed to give you feedback on your current level of understanding. Many of the questions on the quiz have additional details and feedback available when the wrong/right answer is chosen. Be sure to read this after you have completed the quiz. This is important even if you scored very well; the additional details will help solidify your understanding of the material.
A word about late or missing quizzes: I understand that sometimes life, minor illness, other classes, and just plain mistakes are made, and a quiz is missed or completed late. I don’t want to be the judge and jury of your misfortune. Sometimes bad things happen. The dropped quizzes and automatic grace period of 2 days per quiz allow you the privacy and flexibility to prioritize without worrying about my judgment or having one mistake result in a major grade impact. This grading does not remove an opportunity to make up a quiz due to an excused absence (see below), but given the generous “drop 2” policy and 2 days grace for grading, I would assume these are rare. The quizzes are open for 7 days; students who anticipate issues with conflicting activities should complete the quizzes earlier in the week. I believe, and hope you agree, this policy is clear, fair, and flexible. I ask in return that if you truly need an exception beyond this built-in flexibility, that you are clear and honest about that need.
Some of the questions for the quizzes are from a question pool. You should not expect second attempts at a quiz to be identical. On a retake, the questions may change. The new questions from the pool may look very similar to the first quiz questions. It is critical if you want to improve your grade that you read and complete each question again carefully, and not just plug in your answers from your first quiz attempt.
Throughout the course, you’ll encounter occasional ungraded survey-style questions—typically placed at the end of quizzes or activities. These questions are worth zero points and will not impact your grade. Their purpose is to give you a chance to reflect on your learning and to help me (your instructor) gauge how the class is progressing.
Your responses help identify what concepts are clear, what might need more explanation, and how I can improve the course in real time. While optional, your honest input is greatly appreciated and contributes to making this a more responsive and effective learning experience for everyone.


MIDTERM AND FINAL EXAM
The midterm exam will be drawn evenly from all lectures, worksheets, and readings that occurred up to that point in the course (Weeks 1-6). The final exam covers all the material after the midterm to the end of the course. It does not test material from prior to the midterm, but it is important to note that much of the code and analytics post-midterm is built on that earlier learning. You are responsible for all assigned material. Students should have a notebook up and running for the exam to assist with validating answers to code completion problems. The exams are proctored using Honorlock. Students are not permitted to use the internet or work with others during the exams.
MIDTERM EXAM: The exam will be open and available to take anytime during the date range in Canvas. This may change slightly from this syllabus if we are behind or some event causes a delay.
FINAL EXAM: The exam will be open and available to take anytime during the date range in Canvas. The dates in this syllabus are the current planned open and close dates for the exam, but Canvas should be your guide.


COLLABORATION
Writing code and performing data analytics is often a collaborative exercise. You are free to discuss on Canvas or elsewhere any materials from the lectures or workbooks. Quizzes, simulations, and exams are individual efforts only. Please do not post answers or solutions from these in the forums or elsewhere online.

Use of Generative AI tools or other AI tools
You are permitted to use generative AI tools (such as ChatGPT, GitHub Copilot, or similar technologies) for most course activities, including the graded quizzes, exercises, and assignments. However, AI tools may not be used during the midterm or final exam, which are intended to assess your individual understanding.

text:
CLASS RECORDING
Students are allowed to record video or audio of class lectures. However, the purposes for which these recordings may be used are strictly controlled. The only allowable purposes are (1) for personal educational use, (2) in connection with a complaint to the university, or (3) as evidence in, or in preparation for, a criminal or civil proceeding. All other purposes are prohibited. Specifically, students may not publish recorded lectures without the written consent of the instructor.
A “class lecture” is an educational presentation intended to inform or teach enrolled students about a particular subject, including any instructor-led discussions that form part of the presentation, and delivered by any instructor hired or appointed by the University, or by a guest instructor, as part of a University of Florida course. A class lecture does not include lab sessions, student presentations, clinical presentations such as patient history, academic exercises involving solely student participation, assessments (quizzes, tests, exams), field trips, private conversations between students in the class or between a student and the faculty or lecturer during a class session.
Publication without permission of the instructor is prohibited. To “publish” means to share, transmit, circulate, distribute, or provide access to a recording, regardless of format or medium, to another person (or persons), including but not limited to another student within the same class section. Additionally, a recording, or transcript of a recording, is considered published if it is posted on or uploaded to, in whole or in part, any media platform, including but not limited to social media, book, magazine, newspaper, leaflet, or third party note/tutoring services. A student who publishes a recording without written consent may be subject to a civil cause of action instituted by a person injured by the publication and/or discipline under UF Regulation 4.040 Student Honor Code and Student Conduct Code.
Should all or part of this class or open study sessions be offered via an online mechanism during this semester, our sessions may be audio visually recorded for students in the class to refer back and for enrolled students who are unable to attend live. Students who participate with their camera engaged or utilize a profile image are agreeing to have their video or image recorded. If you are unwilling to consent to have your profile or video image recorded, be sure to keep your camera off and do not use a profile image. Likewise, students who un-mute during class and participate orally are agreeing to have their voices recorded. If you are not willing to consent to have your voice recorded during these sessions, you will need to keep your mute button activated and communicate exclusively using the ”chat” feature, which allows students to type questions and comments live.

title: QMB3302 Course Re-Write
text:
1. Conceptual Knowledge (6–8 questions)

Core definitions and distinctions from the videos.
Example:

Q: Which AI paradigm is rule-based?


Symbolic *


Statistical


Neural


Hybrid

Feedback:

A: Correct — symbolic AI uses explicit rules.
B: Incorrect — statistical AI uses inference/probabilities.
C: Incorrect — neural AI is pattern-based.
D: Not a recognized category in this course.

title: QMB3302 Course Re-Write
text:
2. Code Reading & Prediction (6–7 questions)

Students read short snippets of Python (or sklearn/LLM outputs later).
Predict the output, identify errors, or interpret results.
Example:

Q: What will this loop print?
for i in range(3):
    print(i*2)


0 2 4 *


1 2 3


2 4 6


0 1 2

Feedback:

A: Correct — loop starts at 0 and multiplies by 2.
B: Wrong — this would require printing i+1.
C: Wrong — loop doesn’t start at 1.
D: Wrong — that’s just printing i, not i*2.

title: QMB3302 Course Re-Write
text:
3. Applied Interpretation (4–5 questions)

Scenario-based items that simulate reasoning in context.
Example:

Q: You are training a spam classifier. Which evaluation metric matters most if you want to minimize false positives (legitimate emails marked as spam)?


Recall


Precision *


Accuracy


F1 Score

Feedback:

A: Incorrect — recall focuses on catching all spam, not avoiding false positives.
B: Correct — precision measures correctness of positive predictions.
C: Misleading — accuracy alone doesn’t handle class imbalance well.
D: Partial — F1 balances precision/recall but doesn’t prioritize false positives specifically.

title: QMB3302 Course Re-Write
text:
4. Challenge/Stretch (1–2 questions)

Trickier, integrative questions to push deeper thinking.
Example:

Q: Which pandas method is MOST efficient for grouping sales data by both region and product?


df.groupby(["region", "product"]) *


df.loc["region"].groupby("product")


df.pivot("region", "product")


df["region"].unique()

Feedback:

A: Correct — groupby with multiple keys aggregates on both dimensions.
B: Wrong — loc doesn’t group.
C: Wrong — pivot reshapes but doesn’t aggregate.
D: Wrong — only lists unique regions, no aggregation.

text:
Full Course Overview











Week
Theme
Focus & Activities
Practice Emphasis (Walkthrough + Practice)
Quiz Emphasis
Simulation/Exam Tie-in




1
What Is Analytics & AI? + Hello Python
• Analytics & AI foundations (symbolic, statistical, neural paradigms). • Data pipelines & decision frameworks. • Hello Python: print, variables, simple math, intro to notebooks.
Run first notebook; print messages; variables & arithmetic; intro list + loop.
AI paradigms; Python basics (print, arithmetic, variables).
Exam: AI paradigms + simple code-reading.


2
Python & Data Foundations
• Python data types, strings, lists, dictionaries. • Control flow (if/else, loops). • Functions.
Write loops, conditionals, small functions; practice with lists/dicts.
Predict loop output; identify data type; function return values.
Simulation/Exam tie-in: apply control flow & functions to clean/process data.


3
Working with Data
• Pandas & numpy basics. • File paths (absolute vs. relative). • Load, clean, filter, group, summarize data.
Load CSV; clean dataset; drop/rename columns; group & aggregate; summary stats.
Pandas methods (.loc, .groupby); interpreting outputs.
Simulation/Exam: dataset cleaning & summary interpretation.


4
Visualization & Integration
• Visualization: matplotlib (line, bar, scatter) + seaborn (hist, box, count). • Integrated workflow: load → clean → summarize → visualize. • Prep for simulation & exam.
Create plots; style/customize charts; full mini-analysis in notebook.
Chart interpretation; correct chart choice.
Simulation: clean + visualize dataset. Exam: AI paradigms + Python code-reading + pandas basics. (No Week 4 quiz.)


5
ML Foundations + Regression & Classification
• What is ML? Supervised vs. unsupervised. • Features, labels, train/test split. • Overfitting & generalization. • Regression (linear regression). • Classification (logistic regression, decision trees, random forests). • Evaluation metrics: confusion matrix, accuracy, precision/recall, F1, ROC/AUC.
Sklearn regression & classification; interpret coefficients & confusion matrices; test thresholds.
Pipeline basics; regression vs. classification; interpreting metrics.
Simulation/Exam: interpret regression & classification outputs; metric choice.


6
NLP & Neural Networks
• Text as data (bag-of-words, TF-IDF). • Sentiment classification demo. • Error analysis in NLP. • Embeddings (conceptual bridge). • Neural networks: perceptrons, hidden layers, activations. • Demo: small feedforward NN.
Build TF-IDF + logistic pipeline; inspect misclassifications; explore simple NN.
Text vectorization; TF-IDF features; sentiment errors; NN basics.
Simulation: interpret NLP model outputs; compare logistic vs. NN.


7
Vision & Recommenders
• Computer Vision: pixels as data, CNN basics (filters, pooling). • Pretrained CNN demo. • Recommenders: collaborative, content-based, hybrid. • Bias & fairness in personalization.
Run pretrained CNN; interpret predictions; build toy recommender; analyze cold-start issue.
CNN basics; CNN output interpretation; recommender strengths/limits.
Simulation: interpret CNN outputs + recommender results.


8
Clustering, Ethics & RL Intro
• Clustering: k-means, elbow/silhouette. • PCA (conceptual). • Ethics: bias, fairness, interpretability. • RL basics: states, actions, rewards, exploration vs. exploitation.
Run k-means; evaluate clusters; short RL demo (multi-armed bandit).
Cluster interpretation; PCA intuition; RL basics.
Simulation: integrated outputs (regression, classification, NLP, clustering). Exam: cumulative ML concepts + RL basics. (No Week 8 quiz.)


9
LLM Foundations
• LLMs vs. earlier NLP pipelines. • Tokens & embeddings. • Transformer basics (attention). • Scaling laws.
Tokenize text; inspect embeddings; trace transformer diagram.
Tokens, embeddings, attention, scaling.
Simulation/Exam: interpret tokenization/embedding outputs.


10
Prompt Engineering & Use Cases
• Prompting basics. • Zero-shot, few-shot, chain-of-thought. • Applied use: summarization, translation, brainstorming, roleplay. • Limits of prompting.
Students replicate & compare prompts; roleplay simulations.
Prompt types; effect of prompt design.
Simulation: design prompts for summarization + decision support.


11
RAG & Fine-Tuning
• Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). • Embeddings for retrieval. • Demo: toy RAG pipeline. • Fine-tuning methods (full vs. parameter-efficient). • RAG vs. fine-tuning trade-offs.
Build toy RAG system; compare vanilla vs. RAG answers.
RAG basics; RAG vs. fine-tuning.
Simulation/Exam: interpret RAG outputs; trade-off questions.


12
LLM Limits, RLHF & Future
• Limits: hallucination, bias, privacy. • Evaluation methods (benchmarks + human eval). • RLHF (alignment strategy). • Case studies (healthcare, education, business). • Future: multimodal, agentic AI, governance.
Analyze flawed LLM outputs; propose fixes with prompting/RAG; discuss RLHF.
LLM risks; RLHF basics; evaluation methods.
Simulation: evaluate LLM outputs for quality/risk. Exam: cumulative LLM concepts + RLHF + risks/future. (No Week 12 quiz.)

title: QMB3302 Course Re-Write
text:
Student outline








Week
Theme
What You’ll Learn & Do




1
What Is Analytics & AI? + Hello Python
Explore what analytics and AI are, how different AI systems work (rules, statistics, patterns), and run your very first Python notebook.


2
Python & Data Foundations
Learn Python basics: variables, data types, lists, dictionaries, loops, and functions. Write your own simple programs.


3
Working with Data
Use Python’s data tools (pandas, numpy) to load, clean, and summarize real datasets. Learn about file paths and how to organize data.


4
Visualization & Integration
Create charts with matplotlib and seaborn. Combine skills to clean, analyze, and visualize a dataset end-to-end.


5
Machine Learning Foundations
Learn how machines “learn” from data. Build models for predicting numbers (regression) and categories (classification). Practice interpreting results and model accuracy.


6
Text & Neural Networks
Discover how AI understands text (bag-of-words, TF-IDF). Build a simple sentiment classifier. Learn what neural networks are and how they work.


7
Vision & Recommenders
Explore computer vision (how AI “sees” images with CNNs). Learn how recommendation systems work (Netflix, Spotify). Test a pretrained vision model and a toy recommender.


8
Clustering, Ethics & Reinforcement Learning
Learn unsupervised learning (clustering). Discuss bias, fairness, and transparency in AI. Explore reinforcement learning basics (states, actions, rewards).


9
LLM Foundations
Dive into large language models (LLMs). Learn about tokens, embeddings, transformers, and why scaling makes LLMs powerful.


10
Prompt Engineering & Use Cases
Practice designing prompts. Explore applied uses of LLMs: summarization, translation, brainstorming, and roleplay. Learn limits of prompting.


11
Retrieval & Fine-Tuning
Learn how to make LLMs smarter: retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) and fine-tuning. Compare plain vs. enhanced models.


12
LLM Limits, RLHF & Future
Evaluate risks of LLMs (hallucinations, bias, privacy). Learn about RLHF (reinforcement learning from human feedback). Discuss future trends: multimodal AI, agentic systems, governance.

Week 1

Video List









Header
Video Title
Length (min)
Content Bullets




Welcome
Welcome to the Course & How It Works
8
• Introduce course structure (3 sections + applied modules) • Explain assessment system (quizzes, simulations, exams, applied modules) • Set expectations for weekly workload (~12 hours) • Encourage active practice + self-checking


What is Analytics & AI?
Definitions of Analytics and AI
10
• Define analytics vs. artificial intelligence • Emphasize AI = data + models + logic • Examples of analytics (descriptive, predictive, prescriptive) vs. AI tools



Data + Models + Logic: The Core of AI Systems
10
• Explain the “triangle” of AI: data sources, modeling methods, decision rules • Walk through simple pipeline (input → model → output) • Example: weather forecast → model → decision (carry umbrella)


AI Paradigms
Symbolic (Rule-Based) AI
8
• What symbolic AI is (rules, expert systems, logic trees) • Strengths: transparent, interpretable • Weaknesses: brittle, hard to scale • Example: medical expert system (if fever + cough → flu)



Statistical (Inference-Based) AI
8
• Definition: probabilistic inference from data • Key idea: regression, Bayes, classifiers • Example: spam filters, credit risk scoring • Strengths vs. weaknesses (requires good data)



Neural (Pattern-Based) AI
12
• What neural networks are: pattern-based learning • Biological inspiration (neurons, connections) • Example: speech recognition, image recognition • Pros: adapts well to complex data; cons: opaque/black box


Data Pipelines & Decision Frameworks
How Systems Acquire Data (Sensors, APIs, Scraping, User Input)
10
• Four main sources of data (sensors, APIs, scraping, input) • Examples: FitBit → sensor; Twitter → API; scraping e-commerce sites • Role of data ingestion in AI system design



From Data Pipeline to Decision Frameworks
8
• What a decision framework is (rules for using model output) • Example: recommendation engine → “what to watch next” • Show how poor data pipelines → bad decisions


Hello Python
Setting Up & Running Your First Notebook (Colab/Jupyter)
10
• How to open Colab/Jupyter notebook • Difference between code vs. markdown cells • Running a cell with Shift+Enter • Saving and downloading notebooks



Hello Python: Printing, Variables, Simple Math
12
• First code: print("Hello AI") • Assigning variables (x=5, y=2) • Arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, **) • Printing outputs in sentences (print("Result:", x+y))



Mini-Lab Walkthrough: Lists and Loops Intro
14

title: QMB3302 Course Re-Write
text:
Section 2
The arc of Section 2

Week 5 → 6: Core supervised learning (regression → classification) + evaluation literacy.
Week 7: Breadth with depth on NLP, brief exposure to vision and recommenders (conceptual).
Week 8: Unsupervised thinking + ethics/interpretability to round out applied ML judgment.












Week
Theme
Focus & Activities
Practice Emphasis
Quiz Emphasis
Simulation/Exam Tie-in




5
ML Foundations + Regression & Classification
• What is ML? Supervised vs. unsupervised. • Features, labels, train/test split. • Overfitting & generalization. • Regression (linear regression, R², RMSE). • Classification (logistic regression, decision trees, random forests). • Evaluation metrics: confusion matrix, accuracy, precision, recall, F1, ROC/AUC.
Run sklearn regression & classification; interpret coefficients, confusion matrices, ROC curves; test threshold adjustment.
ML pipeline basics; regression vs. classification; interpreting R²/RMSE, confusion matrix, and ROC/AUC.
Simulation (Week 8): interpret regression & classification outputs in business context. Exam (Week 8): supervised pipeline, regression/classification outputs, metric choice.


6
NLP & Neural Networks
• Representing text as data (bag-of-words, TF-IDF). • Sentiment classification demo. • Embeddings (conceptual). • Neural network basics: perceptrons, hidden layers, activation functions. • Demo: simple feedforward NN in Keras. • How neural nets power modern NLP.
Build TF-IDF + logistic pipeline; inspect vocabulary & misclassifications; explore a simple NN model.
Text vectorization; TF-IDF interpretation; sentiment error analysis; NN basics (layers, activation, overfitting).
Simulation: interpret NLP model outputs, diagnose misclassifications. Exam: NLP pipeline reading; NN conceptual understanding.


7
Vision & Recommenders (Deep Learning Applications)
• Vision: Pixels as features, CNN intuition (filters, pooling). • Pretrained CNN demo for image classification. • Recommenders: Collaborative vs. content-based vs. hybrid. • Strengths & weaknesses (cold start, popularity bias). • Deep learning framing: why CNNs are better than raw pixels.
Run pretrained CNN (Keras); interpret predictions; build simple recommender (user–item matrix); analyze cold-start issue.
CNN basics; interpreting CNN output; recommender strengths/limits.
Simulation: interpret CNN output + recommender system results. Exam: conceptual CNN/recommender items; interpreting outputs.


8
Clustering, Ethics & RL Intro
• Clustering: k-means, elbow/silhouette methods. • PCA (conceptual). • Ethics: bias, fairness, interpretability. • Reinforcement Learning (intro): states, actions, rewards, exploration vs. exploitation. • Examples: games, robotics.
Run k-means; evaluate different k; interpret clusters; short RL demo (multi-armed bandit).
When clustering is appropriate; interpreting clusters; fairness; RL basics.
Simulation (Week 8): integrated scenario → regression, classification, NLP, clustering outputs. Proctored Exam (Week 8): cumulative ML concepts + RL basics. (No Week 8 quiz.)

Logistic Regression Classifier

Header
Video Title

NLP Foundations
Text as Data: From Words to Numbers
10

text:
Section 3











Week
Theme
Focus & Activities

9
LLM Foundations
• What are LLMs? Tokens, embeddings, transformers. • Compare with earlier paradigms (symbolic/statistical/NN). • Attention mechanism (conceptual). • Why LLMs scale with data + parameters. • Demo: tokenization + embeddings visualization.

• Prompt design: zero-shot, few-shot, chain-of-thought. • Applications: summarization, translation, brainstorming, roleplay. • Limitations of prompting. • Demo: prompt engineering with examples.

• Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): what it is, why it matters. • Embedding search + external knowledge. • Fine-tuning vs. prompt-tuning. • Demo: simple retrieval pipeline (toy documents).
Walk through a toy RAG setup; inspect retrieved docs; contrast baseline vs. RAG response.
Identify when to use RAG; differences between fine-tuning vs. prompt-tuning.
Simulation: interpret RAG outputs and explain why retrieval improves accuracy. Exam: conceptual items on RAG/fine-tuning trade-offs.


12
LLM Limits, Risks & Future
• Risks: hallucinations, bias, privacy, misuse. • Evaluation frameworks: benchmarks, human eval. • RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback) as alignment strategy. • Industry case studies (education, healthcare, business). • Future trends in generative AI.
Evaluate outputs for hallucination/bias; discuss mitigation strategies; reflect on case study.
Identify risks; RLHF basics; evaluation methods.
Simulation (Week 12): analyze LLM outputs for quality + risks; propose prompts/mitigations. Exam (Week 12): cumulative Section 3 (LLM architecture, prompts, RAG, risks, RLHF). (No standalone weekly quiz in Week 12.)

Video Title
Length (min)

6
• Recap Section 2 (supervised, NLP, CNNs, clustering, RL) • Frame LLMs as the next paradigm shift • Preview: Weeks 9–12 = LLM foundations → prompts → RAG → risks/future


What Are Large Language Models?
From NLP Pipelines to LLMs
10
• Recap old NLP: bag-of-words, TF-IDF, logistic classifiers • Why they struggled (context loss, sparsity) • LLMs as sequence-to-sequence models with deep neural nets • Examples: GPT, Claude, LLaMA


Tokens & Embeddings
Understanding Tokens
8
• What a token is (words, subwords, characters) • Why subwords matter (BPE, WordPiece) • Demo: tokenize simple sentence • Show how different tokenization changes length



Embeddings: Meaning in Numbers
10
• Each token mapped to vector space • Similar tokens cluster together • Example: king–queen–man–woman analogy • Demo: small embedding visualization


Transformers
Transformer Architecture Basics
12
• Input → embeddings → transformer layers → output • Layers stack to learn context • Key advantage: parallelization vs. RNNs • Why transformers scale better



The Attention Mechanism (Conceptual)

• “Attention” = model learns what words matter most • Show simple example: “The cat sat on the mat” (focus on “cat”) • Query, Key, Value intuition • Why attention beats fixed context windows



Scaling Laws of LLMs
8

Week 10









Header
Video Title
Length (min)

Welcome Back & Goals

What Is Prompt Engineering?

Zero-Shot, Few-Shot, and Chain-of-Thought
12

Applied Use Cases
Summarization & Translation

Brainstorming & Creative Use

Limits of Prompting

Week 11









Header
Video Title

Welcome Back & Goals

6

Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)
What Is RAG?
8

Fine-Tuning Basics

Approaches to Fine-Tuning

Video Title
Length (min)

Limits of LLMs
Hallucinations & Reliability

8

RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback)
What Is RLHF?
10
• Define RLHF as aligning LLMs with human preferences • Training loop: pretraining → supervised fine-tuning → RLHF • Reward models & preference data



Why RLHF Matters
8
• Prevents harmful outputs • Makes responses more useful/helpful • Still imperfect (reward hacking, bias transfer)


The Future of LLMs & Generative AI
Case Studies & Trends
12
• Case study: LLMs in healthcare (diagnosis, risks) • Case study: LLMs in education (personalized tutoring, integrity issues) • Case study: LLMs in business (automation, decision support) • Future: multimodal models, agentic AI, AI governance

title: Week0
text:
Purpose and Importance

“Humans experience peak motivation when working on tasks that are just beyond their current ability. Not too hard.
Not too easy.
Just right.” ~ James Clear, Atomic Habits

title: Week0
text:
Too Pessimistic



“No one here can learn this stuff.”
“It’s too complex and requires years of calculus and matrix algebra…”
Requires “a secret decoder ring.”

→ Leads to disengagement → despair → and dramatic emails about dropping the class.





“I’ll never get there”

title: Week0
text:
Too Optimistic



“This is so easy!”
“Each of you will become an expert in multivariate statistics by tomorrow.”
Unrealistic expectations → frustration and loss of motivation.





“why bother?”

title: Week0
text:
Just Right



DBA students from any background, even with no prior experience, can:

Learn this material.

Build a solid foundation.

Continue learning effectively.


“Just right” may differ for everyone.





“I made it!”

title: Week0
text:
Key Takeaway

Just right: start from where you are.

Build a foundation to continue learning.

I’ll assume no prior experience (though I know that’s not strictly true).

title: Week0

Lectures + applied examples.
In-class exercises.
Open-book quizzes.
Collaborative problem solving.

You’ll form a team.

Graded for completion only.

A good college effort is 100%. If you call it in, it’s 0%.

Open book, open notes, open Google. Anything goes.

Wrong answers explain why they’re wrong.

Two attempts per quiz.
Review feedback - it is important for the inperson quizzes.

Second in-class quiz: higher stakes — cumulative coverage. Hard, this one exam will have the largest impact on your grade.

title: Week0
text:
💡 Why R?
R is a programming language built for data analysis, reproducibility, and transparency.
We use R instead of point-and-click software (like SPSS) because it allows us to:

See every analytical step: code is documentation.

Reproduce results easily (important in research and consulting).

Scale from simple stats to complex models without changing tools.

Integrate code + visuals + narrative (as you see in this document).

Automate and share workflows with collaborators.

title: Week0
text:
📦 Getting Started
# Install packages if needed
# install.packages(c("tidyverse", "janitor"))

library(tidyverse)

title: Foundations of Analytics & AI
text:
Foundations of Analytics & AI

Course Textbook
Welcome to the online textbook for the course. It is organized to provide a clear, structured pathway through the foundational ideas and practical techniques of analytics and artificial intelligence. Each week’s chapter includes:

An explaination of the key/core concepts and our objectives for the week.

Demonstrations (where applicable) and worked examples

Links to downloadable code associated with the topics in the lectures.

Practice sections and applied exercises

Short conceptual notes to reinforce key ideas

This site is designed to complement the in-class experience while remaining accessible for self-study. All materials can be viewed online and code files can be downloaded from the course repository. The code in github and on Canvas is the same. The data for this course is stored in Canvas.




How to Use This Textbook
The material is organized into three types:

1. Weekly Modules
These chapters follow the course schedule and lectures. The readings from the text are not identical to the lectures, but they are close. The readings introduce new concepts, connect them to analytics and AI practice, and provide examples to run independently.
Start here:

Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?

Week 2 – Python Basics

Week 3 – Data Structures & Pandas

Week 4 – From Data to Models





2. Practical Guides (Task-Oriented Documentation)
These pages provide focused instructions for installing tools, configuring environments, and resolving common issues.

How to Install Python

Installing the Course requirements.txt

Using Google Colab

These guides remain relevant throughout the semester and may be updated as tools evolve.




Course Learning Philosophy
This textbook is built around two related objectives:

AI Literacy: developing conceptual understanding of modern analytics and AI systems. How they work, where they succeed, and where they sometimes fail.

Job-Relevant Skills: Translating these concepts into practical, executable workflows using Python and contemporary tools.

Each week reinforces both trajectories: one conceptual, one applied.



Accessing Code and Data
All example code for the course is maintained in the main GitHub repository:

Code folder: code/ (available in GitHub and Canvas) Data folder: data/ (available in Canvas only)

You may download the entire repository as a .zip file or clone it directly.
Links to specific scripts and notebooks appear at the end of each week’s chapter.



Need Help?
If you encounter technical issues with installation, environments, or package setup, consult the Guides section using the navigation bar above. These pages provide step-by-step instructions tailored for this course.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
text:
Welcome to the course. This week, our goal is orientation:

Understand how the course is structured (4 weeks Python, 4 weeks ML, 4 weeks LLMs).
Clarify expectations and workflow.
Get a big-picture view of analytics and AI.
Run your first Python code and confirm your environment is set up correctly.

We will use the same pattern every week:

This HTML file acts as your mini-textbook.
Code blocks are written in Python and can be executed in a notebook or VS Code.
Quarto will extract all Python code into a single file for the week: week01_main.py.







Note



How to use this document

Read each section in order.
Run each Python code block in your environment.
Keep the generated week01_main.py, you can reuse functions and examples later.




This course pursues two complementary objectives because modern analytics and AI work demands both conceptual understanding and practical capability. On one hand, you need AI literacy, in this case what I mean by that is “a clear grasp of how data, models, and logic interact; how different AI paradigms operate; and how to interpret the behavior, limits, and risks of the systems you will use.” On the other hand, today’s employers expect job-ready skills: that is “the ability to run and troubleshoot basic Python code, understand and work with data pipelines, evaluate model outputs, write effective prompts, and understand when and how to apply different AI tools.” These two layers reinforce each other. The literacy perspective helps you reason about how AI systems work, and the applied skills prepare you to use those systems responsibly and effectively in real decision-making contexts. Together, they form the foundation for the rest of the course.


By the end of Week 1, you should be able to:

Distinguish between analytics and artificial intelligence as conceptual frameworks for data-driven decision-making.
Explain the foundational components shared by nearly all AI systems: data, models, and logic.
Describe the three major AI paradigms: symbolic, statistical, and neural—and understand how modern systems combine them.
Outline the high-level flow of a data pipeline, from raw data ingestion to features, models, and business decisions.
Recognize where Python fits into the broader ecosystem of analytics and AI tools.




By the end of Week 1, you should be able to:

Navigate the file system using a terminal (pwd, ls/dir, cd) and understand the difference between relative and absolute paths.
Open a project folder in VS Code, run a Python file, and interpret its output.
Write and execute simple Python statements—including basic arithmetic, variables, and print()—to test your environment.
Install required packages from a requirements.txt file and verify your setup by successfully importing key libraries.
Understand, at a conceptual level, what a virtual environment is and why modern analytics/AI workflows rely on environment isolation.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
text:
2.1 Definitions of Analytics and AI
At a high level, analytics and artificial intelligence (AI) are both about using data to support or automate decisions, but they emphasize different things.

Business analytics typically focuses on:

Descriptive analytics – summarizing what has happened.
Diagnostic analytics – understanding why it happened.
Predictive analytics – estimating what is likely to happen.
Prescriptive analytics – recommending what should be done.

Artificial intelligence (AI) focuses on:

Systems that perform tasks that normally require human intelligence, such as:

Perception (vision, speech).
Language understanding and generation.
Planning and decision-making.
Learning from experience.



In practice, the boundary between “analytics” and “AI” is blurry. Many AI systems are built on the same foundations as predictive analytics (data, models, and logic), but at larger scale and with more autonomy.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
section: 2.2 Data + Models + Logic: The Core of AI Systems
text:
2.2 Data + Models + Logic: The Core of AI Systems
Most AI systems—whether simple dashboards or large language models—can be decomposed into three core components:

Data – observations about the world (transactions, clicks, images, text, sensor streams).
Models – mathematical or statistical mappings from inputs to outputs.
Logic – rules about when and how to apply models, and what to do with the outputs.

A simple example:

Data: historical customer purchases.
Model: a classifier that estimates whether a new customer will respond to an offer.
Logic: if predicted probability > 0.7, send a personalized promotion; otherwise, do nothing.

We will reuse this data + models + logic lens throughout the course when we analyze more complex systems.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
section: From Data Pipeline to Decision Frameworks
text:
From Data Pipeline to Decision Frameworks
A decision framework links model outputs to business actions. A simplified pipeline:

Raw data → transformed into features.
Model processes features and produces a score or prediction.
Decision rule or policy maps predictions to actions.
Actions produce outcomes, which generate new data and feedback.

Example:

Features: recency, frequency, and monetary value of customer purchases.
Model: logistic regression predicting probability of churn.
Policy: customers with predicted churn > 0.6 receive an automated retention offer.

Throughout the course, we will move from understanding these basic components to building concrete models and LLM-driven systems.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
text:
Setting Up & Running Python
Once you have your environment (VS Code or equivalent) configured, you should be able to:

Create a new python file.
Type Python code in that file.
Run the file (or parts of it) and see the result.

Try the classic example:

2 + 2

4


You should see the result:
4
Now add a variable and print it:

x = 2
x + 2

4



print(x)

2


You have just:

Declared a variable x.
Performed arithmetic with it.
Printed the value to the screen.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
section: Hello Python: Printing, Variables, Simple Math
text:
Hello Python: Printing, Variables, Simple Math
Let us extend this to a slightly more meaningful example:

course_name = "Analytics & AI"
weeks = 12
modules = 3

print("Welcome to", course_name)
print("Total weeks:", weeks)
print("Weeks per module:", weeks / modules)

Welcome to Analytics & AI
Total weeks: 12
Weeks per module: 4.0


Key concepts:

We assign values to variables with =.
Python handles integers and floats naturally.
print() sends information to the output so you can see it.

We will explore data types, data structures, and control flow in much more depth in later weeks.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
text:
Terminal & File Navigation Basics
Open your terminal (or integrated terminal in VS Code) and try:
pwd
This command prints your current working directory (where the terminal is “pointing”).
List the files in the current directory:
ls
Change directory into a subfolder (for example, where your course materials live):
cd path/to/your/course/folder
ls






Tip



If you are new to the terminal, treat it as a text-based file explorer. You are doing the same things you would do in Finder or Explorer, but with commands.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
text:
Relative vs Absolute Paths
A path describes where a file or folder is located.

An absolute path starts from the root of the file system:

/Users/yourname/Documents/course/week01 (macOS / Linux)
C:\Users\yourname\Documents\course\week01 (Windows)

A relative path is interpreted relative to your current working directory:

data/customers.csv
../common/code


Understanding relative paths is important when you:

Load data files from Python.
Import code from another folder.
Run scripts from different locations.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
text:
Basic Shell Commands
Here is a minimal set of commands you should recognize:
pwd          # print working directory
ls           # list files and folders
cd folder    # change into a folder
cd ..        # move up one level
mkdir src    # create a new folder named 'src'
rm file.txt  # remove a file (use with care)
You do not need to memorize a large catalog of commands. Focus on becoming comfortable:

Finding the correct folder.
Listing its contents.
Navigating up and down the directory tree.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
text:
Virtual Environments Overview
A virtual environment is a self-contained Python installation with its own packages. It prevents conflicts between projects.
Conceptually:

Your computer can have many Python projects.
Each project can have different package versions.
A virtual environment keeps those dependencies isolated.

Later, we will:

Create a virtual environment for this course.
Install all required packages into that environment.
Activate it whenever we work on course materials.

You do not need to master all of this today; Week 1’s main goal is to understand what environments are and why we use them.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
section: Create or Activate a Virtual Environment
text:
Create or Activate a Virtual Environment
If you are using python -m venv, a typical workflow (from your course folder) is:
python -m venv .venv
Then activate the environment:

On macOS / Linux:
source .venv/bin/activate
On Windows (PowerShell):
.venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1

Your terminal prompt should change to indicate the environment is active (for example, it may show (.venv)).

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
text:
Install Packages from requirements.txt
Assuming requirements.txt is in your course folder:
pip install -r requirements.txt
A key instruction above is “from your course folder”. You need to be in the right directory to run the requirements.txt file, and that file needs to be in that directory. If you get an error, one of those two things is the likely culprit. Review how the terminal works again, and how to find and change where you are.
Watch the output and confirm that packages install without errors.

title: Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?
text:
Verify Your Setup in Python
Create a new Python file and run a simple import test.

import sys

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

print("Python version:", sys.version)
print("NumPy version:", np.__version__)
print("Pandas version:", pd.__version__)
print("Environment setup looks good!")

Python version: 3.13.2 | packaged by Anaconda, Inc. | (main, Feb  6 2025, 12:55:35) [Clang 14.0.6 ]
NumPy version: 2.3.4
Pandas version: 2.3.3
Environment setup looks good!


If this code runs without errors, your environment is ready for Week 2.

title: Week 1
text:
Purpose and Importance

“Humans experience peak motivation when working on tasks that are just beyond their current ability. Not too hard.
Not too easy.
Just right.” ~ James Clear, Atomic Habits

title: Week 1
text:
Too Pessimistic



“No one here can learn this stuff.”
“It’s too complex and requires years of calculus and matrix algebra…”
Requires “a secret decoder ring.”

→ Leads to disengagement → despair → and dramatic emails about dropping the class.





“I’ll never get there”

title: Week 1
text:
Too Optimistic



“This is so easy!”
“Each of you will become an expert in multivariate statistics by tomorrow.”
Unrealistic expectations → frustration and loss of motivation.





“why bother?”

title: Week 1
text:
Just Right



DBA students from any background, even with no prior experience, can:

Learn this material.

Build a solid foundation.

Continue learning effectively.


“Just right” may differ for everyone.





“I made it!”

title: Week 1
text:
Key Takeaway

Just right: start from where you are.

Build a foundation to continue learning.

I’ll assume no prior experience (though I know that’s not strictly true).

title: Week 1
text:
Syllabus Overview

Lectures + applied examples.
In-class exercises.
Open-book quizzes.
Collaborative problem solving.

title: Week 1
text:
Exercises: Practice Through Doing

Exercises occur during class sessions.

In-Class Exercises: Collaborative Learning

You’ll form a team.
Submit your work during class.
Graded for completion only.

A good college effort is 100%. If you call it in, it’s 0%.

title: Week 1
text:
At-Home Quizzes

Open book, open notes, open Google. Anything goes.
Read the quiz notes carefully:

Right answers explain why they’re right.
Wrong answers explain why they’re wrong.

Two attempts per quiz.
Review feedback - it is important for the inperson quizzes.

title: Week 1
text:
In-Class Quizzes

Open your own notes (typed or handwritten).

No computer, no textbook, no instructor materials.
One attempt only.
These are (obviously) harder.

Second in-class quiz: higher stakes — cumulative coverage. Hard, this one exam will have the largest impact on your grade.

title: Week 1
text:
💡 Why R?
R is a programming language built for data analysis, reproducibility, and transparency.
We use R instead of point-and-click software (like SPSS) because it allows us to:

See every analytical step: code is documentation.

Reproduce results easily (important in research and consulting).

Scale from simple stats to complex models without changing tools.

Integrate code + visuals + narrative (as you see in this document).

Automate and share workflows with collaborators.

glimpse(ames)

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
This document will walk you through the steps to:

Install Python 3

Install Visual Studio Code (VS Code)

Configure VS Code to run .py files

Verify that everything is working correctly

You only need to complete this setup once on your computer.
After that, you will be able to run all course examples and labs.






Tip



If you get stuck at any point:
Installing this should be straightforward. LLMs can be a great way to problem solve an install. Use UFs Navigator Chat to help you. There is an optional video on this in the course files. Still stuck? Reach out to a TA and let them help you out. Use the course guidelines for how to ask good questions to request help.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
On Windows?

Open the Start Menu.

Type cmd and press Enter to open the Command Prompt.

In the black window, type:

py --version
or
python --version

Press Enter.


If you see something like Python 3.10.11, Python 3 is already installed.

If you see an error or a much older version (like Python 2.x), you should install a current version.
Most MAC’s will have Python installed, but this is for your system, you want to install it again. We don’t want to be making changes to the factory installed Python.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
on macOS?

Open Terminal (Spotlight → type Terminal).

Type:

python3 --version

Press Enter.


If you see Python 3.x.x, you have Python 3.

For the most part, you should install a new version, even if you see this.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
on Linux?

Open a terminal.

Type:

python3 --version

Press Enter.

If Python 3 is not installed, follow the installation steps below.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
Windows Installation

Click Download Python 3.x.x for Windows.

Run the installer (python-3.x.x.exe) after it downloads.

On the first screen:

Check the box that says:
“Add Python 3.x to PATH”

Then click “Install Now”.

Wait for the installation to finish.

Click “Close” when done.


Verify Python on Windows
Open Command Prompt again and type:
py --version
or
python --version
You should now see Python 3.x.x.
If you don’t, restart your computer and try again.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
macOS Installation

On https://www.python.org/downloads/, choose “Download Python 3.x.x for macOS”.

Open the downloaded .pkg file.

Follow the installer prompts and accept the defaults.


Verify Python on macOS
Open Terminal and type:
python3 --version
You should see Python 3.x.x.
If you don’t, log out and back in, or restart your machine.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
Linux Installation (brief)
On many Linux distributions, Python 3 is already installed.
If not, you can install it with your package manager. For example:

Ubuntu / Debian:
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install python3 python3-pip
Fedora:
sudo dnf install python3 python3-pip

After installation, check:
python3 --version

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
Download and Install VS Code

Go to: https://code.visualstudio.com/

Click Download for your operating system (Windows, macOS, or Linux).

Run the installer and accept the defaults.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
section: Install the Python Extension in VS Code
text:
Install the Python Extension in VS Code

Open VS Code.

On the left sidebar, click the Extensions icon (four squares).

In the search bar, type: Python.

Find the extension published by Microsoft (it should be at the top).

Click Install.

VS Code will now understand and support Python files.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
section: Running the Script (VS Code Integrated Terminal)
text:
Running the Script (VS Code Integrated Terminal)

In VS Code, open the Terminal:

View → Terminal, or

Press Ctrl+` (Windows/Linux)

Press Ctrl+Shift+` (macOS, depending on keybindings)

Make sure the terminal is using the correct folder. You should see a path that ends with week01.
Type one of the following commands and press Enter:

On Windows:
py test_setup.py
or
python test_setup.py
On macOS/Linux:
python3 test_setup.py

You should see:

Python is working, awesome!
If you see that message, your environment is ready.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
“Python is not recognized” on Windows
If you see:
'python' is not recognized as an internal or external command
or
'py' is not recognized...
Try:

Restarting your computer.

Running the installer again and making sure “Add Python to PATH” is checked.

title: Setting Up Python for This Course
text:
Scripts not finding data files
Make sure:

Your .py script and your data files are in the same folder, or

Your script uses the correct relative path, like:

import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv("data/housing_prices.csv")
If you move files around, update the paths accordingly.

title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
Welcome to the course!
This course is designed to introduce you to the basics of data analytics and machine learning using the powerful programming language Python. No prior programming experience is required. The course is structured into two main sections. Students will first learn the basics of Python and how to write programs in Weeks 1-6. Weeks 6+ progress to using Python to solve real world analytical problems.
Why learn Python? Python is rapidly becoming the language of choice fordata scientists, data analysts, and those working on cutting edge business analytics. It is the tool of choice for this work at companies such as Google,Amazon, Facebook, IBM, NASA, Accenture, and Deloitte. It is also free to use, making it widely available to firms and users around the world. Beyond business analytics, Python is often used as a general programming language to automate tasks.
Why learn machine learning? Businesses today often use data to solve complex problems. A business that ignores the data it generates is at a significant disadvantage. The skills required to analyze and interpret that data are in short supply. A basic understanding of Artificial Intelligence and how it is used in business will be critical for tomorrows business leaders. Regardless of the domain a student decides to work in after graduation, it is likely that AI skills will make them more competitive in the job market.

title: QMB3302 Foundations of Analytics and AI
text:
COURSE OBJECTIVES

Programming: Install Python and Jupyter notebooks
Programming: Read basic Python programs, recognizing the structures and patterns within, and be able to explain how they work
Programming: Write and run Python scripts to manipulate, clean, and prepare data for analysis
Programming: Debug and problem solve coding errors
Analytics: Produce basic visualizations using standard Python libraries
Analytics: Produce basic statistical summaries of continuous and categorical data
Artificial Intelligence: Understand the different AI models and approaches businesses use
Artificial Intelligence: Build a simple machine learning model
Applied Analytics and AI: Understand how Python and other business analytics programs can be used in business applications

text:
AI COURSE CONTENT
Each program at the University of Florida designated as an AI course has Student Learning Outcomes (SLOs) that describe the knowledge, skills, and attitudes that students are expected to acquire throughout the program.
This course fits into the UF AI Category “Build AI”. In this course, students will: Evaluate & Create AI: Higher-order thinking skills (e.g., evaluate, appraise, predict, design) with AI applications. AI course content is over 50 percent.
This course has the following identified Student Learning Outcomes, with the corresponding week they are assessed:

SLO1: Identify, describe, and/or explain the components, requirements, and/or characteristics of AI. (Weeks 3, 4, 6-13, simulation 1)
SLO2: Recognize, identify, describe, define, and/or explain applications of AI in multiple domains. (Weeks 6-13, simulation 2)
SLO3: Select and/or utilize AI tools and techniques appropriate to a specific context and application. (Weeks 6, 8, 9, 10, Week 13, simulation 2)
SLO5: Assess the context-specific value or quality of AI tools and applications. (Weeks 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, simulation 2)
